titlestmt.titleproper: Finding aid for the Westwood-Holmby Historical Society records, 1907-2014 LSC.2253
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Caitlin Denny, April 2016; machine-readable finding aid created by Caroline Cubé.

p.date: Online finding aid last updated 10 March 2017.

address.addressline: Room A1713, Charles E. Young Research Library

physdesc.extent: (15 boxes, 12 oversized flat boxes, 5 flat boxes, 1 shoe box, 1 poster tube, 1 oversize panorama enclosure)

did.abstract: The collection is comprised of administrative, organizational and membership files of the Westwood-Holmby Historical Society as well as materials about Los Angeles gathered between 1989 and 2014 through the Research Committee of the WHHS. Historical research and community support were the main objectives of WHHS.
did.physloc:
Portions of the collection stored off-site. Advance notice is required for access to the collection. All requests to access special collections materials must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.
Oversize panoramic photographs (box 35) held on B-level, range 24.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. All requests to access special collections materials must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: CONTAINS AUDIOVISUAL MATERIALS: This collection contains processed audiovisual materials. All requests to access digital materials must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use and Reproduction
userestrict.p: Property rights to the objects belong to UCLA Library Special Collections. All other rights, including copyright, are retained by the creators and their heirs. It is the responsibility of the researcher to determine who holds the copyright and pursue the copyright owner or his or her heir for permission to publish where The UC Regents do not hold the copyright.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Westwood-Holmby Historical Society Records (Collection 2253). UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, University of California, Los Angeles.

acqinfo.head: Provenance/Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of the Westwood-Holmby Historical Society, 2014.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by Caitlin Denny under the supervision of Courtney Dean in the Center for Primary Research and Training (CFPRT), 2016.

Collections are processed to a variety of levels depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived user interest and research value, availability of staff and resources, and competing priorities. Library Special Collections provides a standard level of preservation and access for all collections and, when time and resources permit, conducts more intensive processing. These materials have been arranged and described according to national and local standards and best practices.

We are committed to providing ethical, inclusive, and anti-racist description of the materials we steward, and to remediating existing description of our materials that contains language that may be offensive or cause harm. We invite you to submit feedback about how our collections are described, and how they could be described more accurately, by filling out the form located on our website: Report Problematic Content and Description in UCLA's library collections and archives.

bioghist.head: Biography/History
bioghist.p: The Westwood-Holmby Historical Society (1989 – 2014) was a non-profit public benefit organization founded as an outgrowth of Westwood's 60th Anniversary celebration. WHHS was a volunteer led and run organization dedicated to the research and documentation of people, places and events of historical significance in Westwood-Holmby, a neighborhood in west Los Angeles, California. They were active in building their own archives of photographs, newspaper clippings and oral histories among other records that were both collected and created by the WHHS. Lectures, exhibitions and tours were often curated by WHHS for the community as well as for local schools. Organizational priorities included petitioning for cultural heritage sites and being vocal in the bureaucratic measures that determine historical status in Los Angeles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: In this collection are the administrative and research materials pertaining to the Westwood-Holmby Historical Society. Administrative files include bylaws, meeting minutes and various correspondence records. Files relating to specific events that WHHS programmed are also included in this collection and contain flyers, posters and photographs about and documenting their events and lectures. Membership files like member lists and guestbooks can also be found in this collection. WHHS's most active unit was their research committee, who gathered the bulk of the content of this collection between 1989 and 2014. Their research materials include subseries collections that were donated to WHHS: the Rowe Radar Baldwin papers, the Robert and Blanche Campbell papers, and the George Gregson papers. These donated collections revolve around the lives of their donors and their relationship to the Westwood neighborhood. Research committee materials include a large amount of photographs, ephemera, publications and information about the family who developed the neighborhood of Westwood, the Janss family.

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p:
This collection has been arranged in the following series:
Series 1: Administrative, 1989 - 2014
Series 2: Events, 1989 - 2003
Series 3: Membership, 1989 - 2003
Series 4: Historical Research, 1907 - 2014
Subseries 4.1: Rowe Radar Baldwin papers, 1929-1992
Subseries 4.2: Robert and Blanche Campbell papers, 1930-1990
Subseries 4.3: George Gregson Westwood Real Estate papers, 1929-2014
Subseries 4.4: Research Committee, 1907-2010
Subseries 4.5: Oral Histories, 1989-2000

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This first series in the collection focuses on the administrative and legal files of the Westwood-Holmby Historical Society. Articles of incorporation, tax status and by laws accompany organizational level materials like meeting minutes, logo designs and correspondence.

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p: Files at this level are arranged alphabetically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Contains three posters, two copies of an original design promoting Westwood, and the third a poster of the University of California.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The documents in this series represent programmed events and lectures developed by WHHS. The bulk of the series contains photographs, flyers and press releases pertaining to the Celebrate Westwood 60th Committee of which the WHHS was created out of. Other events documented in this series include historical walking tours and guest lectures on historical architectural monuments all within the neighborhood of Westwood.

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p: Files at this level are arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This item is mounted on foam board.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: These files document a few key members of the WHHS, Wendy Kaplan and Greg Fischer. Fischer was on the board of directors for the WHHS as well as a historical walking tour guide of Los Angeles and an advocate for the restoration of historical Los Angeles neighborhood titles. Kaplan was the Founding President of the WHHS until her retirement in 1991. Also in this collection are photographs from member only meetings and lists of members throughout the years in the form of guestbooks and lists.

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p: Files at this level are arranged by subject.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Contains 35mm negatives.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The fourth series in this collection contains the bulk of the materials. The Research Committee within the WHHS was the most active sector of the society due to their mission to preserve and restore historically significant information and architecture relating to Westwood and surrounding neighborhoods in Los Angeles. This series is comprised of five subseries, three of which are small donated collections by people or families who had affluent and honored standing in the Westwood community. Subjects that make appearances in this series are the prominent Westwood families of Janss and Burbank and Los Angeles city planning materials. The city planning materials include tract home maps and advertisements as well as correspondence on infrastructure and architectural developments. The last subseries in this series includes oral histories recorded on cassette and mini cassette as well as transcriptions of those interviews in bound book form.

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p: Files at this level are arranged chronologically unless otherwise stated.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: SERIES CONTAINS AUDIOVISUAL MATERIALS: Audiovisual materials in this collection will require assessment and possible digitization for safe access. To review these audiovisual materials, you must notify the UCLA Library Special Collections Reference Desk in advance of your visit.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Rowe Radar Baldwin was a 1929 UCLA alum. From 1934 to 1938 she wrote a column called Village Raider for the Westwood Hills Press as part of her duties as Publicity Director of the Janss Investment Corporation, for whom she worked from 1929 to 1938. She began writing Village Raider in June 1934 and resigned in April 1938, replaced by Gertrude Harlan. Following, Baldwin worked as UCLA's athletic ticket manager from 1943 to 1973. She was a founding member of the UCLA Gold Shield. Baldwin assisted Westwood-Holmby Historical Society in research for exhibitions and events. In 1975 and 1976, Baldwin assisted Donald Combs in research for History of Westwood exhibit at Contempo Westwood Center. In 1989, Baldwin assisted in the Westwood 60th Anniversary by providing valuable insight and details about the town. Baldwin served as Honorary Society Director of WHHS from 1989 to 1995. These papers were donated from Baldwin to WHHS in 1992. Her papers includes correspondence with Warner Bros studio, UCLA, San Bernardino School District and other individuals and businesses she helped provide with information or photographs of Westwood during her time as a columnist. Newspaper clipping from her column, as well as about Janss Investment Corporation can be found in this subseries. One folder is dedicated to child actress Jane Withers and her interaction with UCLA and Ms. Radar in 1936.

"Village Raider" column copies from Baldwin's scrapbook, 1934 - 1938
"Village Raider" column copies from Baldwin's scrapbook, 1934 - 1938

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Robert and Blanche Campbell were business owners in Westwood in the 1930s to 1980s. They owned and operated Campbell's Bookstore located at 10918 Le Conte Ave. Materials in this subseries include administrative and publicity files associated with Campbell's Bookstore, community service activities of the Campbells, and photographs of the Campbell family. Also included in this subseries are ephemera about the Westwood Village Lions Club and Westwood Village Studio donated by the daughter of Robert and Blanche, Clarice Campbell and her friend Dorothy Ross, daughter of Ruth and Gene Ross.

Geroge Gregson Westwood Real Estate papers

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: George Gregson (Gregovich), 1904 – 1997, was the Vice President for the Janss Investment Corporation. His parents emigrated from Serbia to the United States and raised George in Arizona. Gregson began his career as an appraiser at a mortgage company and worked his way up to executive and then Vice President at the Janss Investment Corporation. After Janss Corp sold the land in Westwood, Gregson continued to own property in Westwood Village, including Linde Medical Plaza land, and various office locations. He was married to Patricia Cluff Janss from January 12th, 1935 until her death in 1939. Included in this subseries are materials related to Mr. Gregson's time at Janss Investment Corporation, titles and deeds of the sale of Westwood Village, and his personal letter opener.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The research committee in the Westwood-Holmby Historical Society was the core of the group's activities and interests. They sought to gain information and insight on their neighborhood in order to protect the rights of and inform landowners as well as register certain sites as historical places. Much of their research ended up contributing to the many exhibitions they had over the years.

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p: Files at this level are arranged chronologically within subjects.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The oral histories in this subseries were recorded interviews conducted by the WHHS between the years of 1989 and 1992. Also included is a two volume bound transcript of separate interviews conducted by the UCLA Center for Oral History Research.
